awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Developing a self-powered pipeline sensing and monitoring system
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation-Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project includes ensuring the safety, security and efficiency of our nation's energy infrastructure by providing self-powered pipeline sensing and monitoring systems. This project will produce a novel approach to provide a reliable power source to enable continuous monitoring of pressurized steam distribution system in energy plants, with an estimated market potential of ~ $2.4 Billion. The technology has a high potential for later commercialization in other energy distribution systems, such as the oil and gas industry. The project will provide training and mentoring on innovation and technology translation to undergraduate, graduate students through a multi-faceted educational plan, including new curriculum development. The educational contributions of this effort include (1) provide students first-hand knowledge of how to translate fundamental scientific research into technology and product development; (2) enhance interdisciplinary education and research programs; (3) broaden the participation and success of underrepresented groups in innovation education through the PIs' ongoing collaborations with existing programs. 

The proposed project is to develop a self-powered sensing and monitoring system to enable continuous monitoring of pipeline operation for our nation's energy infrastructures. Most of these critical infrastructures are located in the areas with difficult access. This presents a significant challenge when using battery powered sensors or monitoring devices for continuous monitoring of pipelines. To solve this problem, a novel conformal thermoelectric generator is proposed in this program to harvest wasted heat in the pipeline for sensor powering. Three technical innovations will be used in this project at materials, devices, and system levels. 1) At the materials level nanostructured oxides will be used to replace conventional telluride-based materials which are toxic, expensive, and low temperature stability. 2) At the device level, a continuous production of thermoelectric devices will be used to reduce the cost of device fabrication and packaging at large-scale. 3) At the system level, new technology for thermoelectric voltage booster and energy storage devices will be used for integration of thermoelectric generator with sensors and monitoring devices. A multi-disciplinary research team will work with two industry partners on technology development to ensure the solutions are practical to the challenges that industry specific.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF PFI-TT project is built upon the machine learning guided conformal thermoelectric generator (cTEG) for underground pipeline monitoring. The team developed a systematic machine learning model for cTEG heat transfer and prototype for powering IoT sensors. The novel design and fabricated cTEG from this study have a great potential for using as power generation or battery backup system since they maintain high thermoelectric (TE) performance under different temperature scenarios.

 

The research team identified various successful approaches for improving the TE performance of cTEG. The team achieved this by creating tailored heat transfer models and employing additive manufacturing for building prototypes. Additionally, the team also designed a suite of machine-learning tools to investigate materials and structural aspects of oxides in the context of cTEG power generation.

 

The scientific contributions of this program included 1) develop heat transfer model to predict cTEG performance with various scenarios; 2) develop a cTEG using a continuous production to reduce the cost of device fabrication and packaging at large scale; 3) develop a thermoelectric voltage booster and energy storage devices for the integration of cTEG with sensors; 4) use artificial intelligence (AI) tool to optimize the TE performance for different applications. This program has identified several cTEG design for underground pipeline monitoring applications and their optimized TE performance. Also, the technique gained from this study can be applied more broadly in other engineering applications, such as building system, smart infrastructure, and sustainable environmental and health applications.

 

The PFI-TT program has provided support for the research endeavors of one postdoctoral scientist, the pursuit of two doctoral theses, and the engagement of numerous master's and undergraduate students in various research projects. The findings and insights generated from this research have been widely shared with the scientific community through the publication of peer-reviewed articles and through numerous invited presentations at both national and international conferences. In addition, this program has played a pivotal role in offering consistent training in entrepreneurship and customer discovery to graduate students, equipping them with valuable skills beyond their academic pursuits. Moreover, it has contributed to the creation of a translational framework designed to analyze potential commercial pathways and assess various options for commercialization, enriching the toolkit available for researchers and entrepreneurs. Furthermore, this PFI-TT project has significantly enriched science and technology education by introducing new curriculum approaches that integrate science and engineering disciplines. These initiatives have effectively increased the participation of underrepresented students and promoted broader engagement in pursuing careers in science and engineering.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2023
Modified by: Na (Luna) Lu
